author: Mawich
title: Mixed feelings
review:
This was never one of my favourite sets as a kid but nor was it one that I disliked.  The excavator is completely out of scale which really detracted from the playability but the overall set was redeemed by the other pieces it came with. 

I loved the construction workers of the time and in particular their helmets and vests they wore (the vests were to disappear within a year or two).  The road signs were another plus topped off with the pick axe and shovel. 

By today's standards this set is very simplistic and with very little play value as an assembled set but it came with a number of parts such as the hinges that were useful for other purposes.

author: peti7788
title: Basic Excavator - which is great!
review:
Another set of transition era. Even the construction philosophy of the mini-wheel era, the minifigure is not compatible with the vehicle, unfortunately you cannot put the minifigure in the vehicle.Now it knows as much compared to today’s sets as a polybag set.

The build

Very basic building technique. However, if you’re lucky and you have the box, there are a couple of full-fledged alternative builds on the back. I think the designer put the digger bucket upside down. In reality, it used to be the other way around. The machine is digging towards itself.

Parts

There are a couple of rare parts: the black hinge, the yellow vest, the 2x2x2 transparent slope brick, stickers.

Minifig

Nothing extra, just a standard smile face. There is only a print on the face. I miss the sticker on the high visibility vest. But photoshop and a good printer can do wonders.

Overall opinion

In fact, the set is completely playable, especially what alternative constructions come with it, with so few parts, excellent! Absolutely recommended!

My mod

It frustrates me that I can’t put the minifigure in the vehicle. Plus I was interested in how I would have solved the task from the parts available in 1978. That was the result:

First, I took off the 2x4 black plate from the top of the chassis. I put a 2x2 turntable and two black tiles in its place. Unfortunately, the original version does not turn, it is fixed. 

And when we’re done digging, we can lock it with a 1x2 brick to keep the turntable from turning.

Unfortunately, the machine is not to scale with the minifigure, but at least it can be put into it.

Since we only have a 4x6 yellow plate, we didn’t fit the control sticks or a steering wheel, but I think it’s still okay compared to the options.

From below, the machine is locked. This solution requires fewer parts and yet has more game value.
